div.head:
Embleme 33. of the Secrets of Nature.
The Hermaphrodite lying like a dead man in darknesse, wants fire.

lg.l: See here the cold and dry Hermaphrodite,
Appears as dismall as a ghost by night:
Fire is the thing hee wants, if that you give,
His Spirits feeling warmth will soone revive.
The Stone's whole virtue in God Vulcan lyes,
Sulphurs in Sol, in Luna Mercurye's.

div.head: Discourse 33.
div.ab:
It is one of the secrets of Nature, that in the cold winter Froggs and-
Horse=leeches lye as it were dead under water, and in the Spring new-
heat of the Sunne operating recover sense and motion, or performe-
the actions of a sensitive life: But if they be found in the waters-
in the winter time, and brought into the aire or a warme house, they
presently begin to move themselves, as in the Summer: From whence
it appears, that they want nothing but externall heat, to excite the
naturall internall heat, and bring it to action: After the same man
ner doe the Philosophers speake of their Hermaphrodite, who, if hee
appears dead lying in darkenesse, requires the heat of fire: Now hee-
is sayd to lye in darkenesse, being left in a darke and most cold win
ters night, that is, remaining in blacknesse, which is a signe of coldnesse,
from which hee ought to be brought to whitenesse by a greater intension
of fire, and by yet a greater, to rednesse: For, as Bodillus in Turba sayth,
nothing is generated without heat, and a bath of vehement heat causeth-
a body to perish, if it be cold it drives it away, but if it be temperate, it
becomes agreable and pleasant to the body. Bonellus in the same sayth,
All things that live doe allso (God soe pleasing) dye: that nature there
fore, which is depriv'd of moisture, being exposd by night, seems like
a dead man, and then that nature requires fire, till the body and Spi
rit of it be turned into earth, and then it becomes dust like to a dead
man in his tombe: these things being accomplished God restores a Spirit
and Soule to it, and all infirmity being taken away our nature is com
forted and amended: It is therefore requisite to burne that matter without
fear Ct: Fire therefore, which destroyes all other things, repaires this, that
which yeilds death to others gives life to this. One onely Phænix there is,
which is restored by fire, which is renewed by flames, and revives out of
ashes, and this being knowne to the Philosophers onely is burnt and
restored to life, whatsoever other men dreame of a bird, I know not-
what, that flyeth, residing noe where, nor seen, but aas a fable. The
Hermaphrodite, of which the Philosophers speake, is of a mixd na
ture, male and female, whereof one passeth into another by the-
operation of heat, for the female is converted into a male, which-
ought not to seem soe strange in the Philosophers worke, it being-
found, if wee may beleive historyes, that many men have allso-
changd their sex: The Poetts make mention of Ceneus, Iphis, and
Tiresias, as Pontanus in the Starrs.
Pæniteat generis tamen et se Cenea malint,
Aut in fæmineam penitus transire figuram: And Ausonius:
Mæret in antiquam Ceneus revocata figuram.
Soe in the Consulship of Licinius Crassus, and Caius Cassius Longinus
Discourse 3.
